items.title: Fishing Boats and City Lights
items.summary: Fishing boats illuminate the Arabian Sea along Indiaâ€™s west coast with green lights designed to attract squid, shrimp, sardines, and mackerel in this nighttime photograph from the International Space Station, orbiting 259 miles above Earth on Dec. 25, 2025. items.title: 125 million-year-old dinosaur with never before seen hollow spikes discovered in China
items.summary: A 125-million-year-old dinosaur just rewrote what we thought we knew about prehistoric life. Scientists in China have uncovered an exceptionally preserved juvenile iguanodontian with fossilized skin so detailed that individual cells are still visible. Even more astonishing, the plant-eating dinosaur was covered in hollow, porcupine-like spikesâ€”structures never before documented in any dinosaur.

items.title: Digistoria - cele mai importante evenimente petrecute pe 18 februarie
items.summary: Digistoria - cele mai importante evenimente petrecute pe 18 februarie

items.title: One stem cell generates 14 million tumor-killing NK cells in major cancer breakthrough
items.summary: Scientists in China have unveiled a breakthrough way to mass-produce powerful cancer-fighting immune cells in the lab. By engineering early-stage stem cells from cord bloodâ€”rather than trying to modify mature natural killer (NK) cellsâ€”they created a streamlined process that generates enormous numbers of highly potent NK cells, including CAR-equipped versions designed to hunt specific cancers.

items.summary: Comisia EuropeanÄƒ a aprobat miercuri Ã®nregistrarea â€Batogului de sturionâ€ din Tulcea Ã®n registrul produselor cu IndicaÈ›ie GeograficÄƒ ProtejatÄƒ (IGP), oferindu-i astfel protecÈ›ie la nivelul Uniunii Europene. Decizia recunoaÈ™te legÄƒtura strÃ¢nsÄƒ dintre acest produs tradiÈ›ional È™i aria geograficÄƒ a judeÈ›ului Tulcea, precum È™i reputaÈ›ia cÃ¢È™tigatÄƒ prin procesul sÄƒu specific de preparare, bazat pe materie primÄƒ provenitÄƒ din acvaculturÄƒ.

items.title: Toxic metals found in bananas after Brazil mining disaster
items.summary: Researchers investigating crops grown in soil contaminated by the 2015 mining disaster in Brazil discovered that toxic metals are moving from the earth into edible plants. Bananas, cassava, and cocoa were found to absorb elements like lead and cadmium, with bananas showing a potential health risk for children under six. Although adults face lower immediate danger, scientists warn that long-term exposure could carry cumulative health consequences.

items.title: Scientists discover brain switches that clear Alzheimerâ€™s plaques
items.summary: Researchers have identified two brain receptors that help the brain clear away amyloid beta, a hallmark of Alzheimerâ€™s disease. By stimulating these receptors in mice, scientists increased levels of a natural amyloid-breaking enzyme, reduced buildup in the brain, and improved memory-related behavior. Because these receptors are common drug targets, the findings could open the door to affordable pill-based treatments with fewer side effects.

items.title: Nearly 200,000 people reveal the real key to heart health
items.summary: A decades-long study of nearly 200,000 adults challenges the low-carb versus low-fat debate. Both eating patterns were tied to lower heart disease risk when they emphasized whole grains, plant-based foods, and healthy fats. Versions filled with refined carbs and animal fats increased risk instead. Quality, not just quantity, appears to make the difference.

items.title: Giving people cash didnâ€™t cause more injuries or deaths
items.summary: As cash transfer programs expand across the United States, critics often warn that giving people money could spark reckless behavior, leading to injuries or even deaths. But a sweeping 11-year analysis of Alaskaâ€™s long-running Permanent Fund Dividend program tells a different story. Researchers examined statewide hospital records and death data and found no increase in traumatic injuries or unnatural deaths after annual payments were distributed.

items.title: Large study finds no link between mRNA COVID vaccine in pregnancy and autism
items.summary: Researchers tracked more than 400 toddlers to see whether mRNA COVID-19 vaccination during or just before pregnancy was linked to autism or developmental delays. After detailed assessments of speech, motor skills, behavior, and social development, they found no meaningful differences between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups. Experts say the results provide strong reassurance about vaccine safety in pregnancy.

items.title: Scientists found a way to plant ideas in dreams to boost creativity
items.summary: Sleeping on a problem might be more powerful than we ever imagined. Neuroscientists at Northwestern University have shown that dreams can actually be nudged in specific directions â€” and those dream tweaks may boost creativity. By playing subtle sound cues during REM sleep, researchers prompted people to dream about unsolved brain teasers they had struggled with earlier. An astonishing 75% of participants dreamed about the cued puzzles, and those puzzles were solved far more often the next day.

items.title: This vegan diet cut insulin use by nearly 30% in type 1 diabetes
items.summary: A low-fat vegan dietâ€”without cutting calories or carbsâ€”may help people with type 1 diabetes significantly reduce how much insulin they need, and how much they spend on it. In a new analysis published in BMC Nutrition, participants following the plant-based plan lowered their daily insulin use by 28%, while those on a portion-controlled diet saw no meaningful change.

items.title: 60,000 years ago humans were already using poisoned arrows
items.summary: Sixty thousand years ago, humans in southern Africa were already mastering natureâ€™s chemistry. Scientists have discovered chemical traces of poison from the deadly gifbol plant on ancient quartz arrowheads found in South Africa â€” the oldest direct evidence of arrow poison ever identified. The find reveals that these early hunters didnâ€™t just invent the bow and arrow earlier than once believed â€” they also knew how to enhance their weapons with toxic plant compounds to make hunts more effective.

items.title: Europeâ€™s â€œuntouchedâ€ wilderness was shaped by Neanderthals and hunter-gatherers
items.summary: Long before agriculture, humans were transforming Europeâ€™s wild landscapes. Advanced simulations show that hunting and fire use by Neanderthals and Mesolithic hunter-gatherers reshaped forests and grasslands in measurable ways. By reducing populations of giant herbivores, people indirectly altered how dense vegetation became. The findings challenge the idea that prehistoric Europe was an untouched natural world.

items.title: This popular diet was linked to a much lower stroke risk
items.summary: A long-term study found that women who closely followed a Mediterranean diet had a much lower risk of stroke. The strongest benefits were seen in women who ate more plant-based foods, fish, and olive oil while cutting back on red meat and saturated fats. Their risk dropped across all major stroke types, including bleeding strokes, which are less commonly studied. The findings suggest diet may be a powerful but overlooked factor in stroke prevention.

items.title: Scientists found a gut compound that helps protect the liver
items.summary: What a mother eats during pregnancy may quietly shape her childâ€™s liver health years down the roadâ€”but new research suggests there may be a way to tip the odds back in a healthier direction. Scientists found that a natural compound made by healthy gut bacteria dramatically reduced fatty liver disease in the offspring of mice whose mothers ate a high-fat, high-sugar diet. The compound, called indole, appeared to protect the liver, improve blood sugar, limit weight gain, and even reshape the gut microbiome in lasting ways.

items.title: For every $1 spent protecting nature, $30 goes to destroying it
items.summary: The world spends billions to protect nature, but trillions are being invested in business activities that harm the environment.

items.title: 11-year streak of record global warming continues, UN weather agency warns
items.summary: The past 11 years have been the warmest in the modern era, while oceans continue to heat up, too, says the UN weather agency.

items.title: UN environment assembly wraps up in Nairobi
items.summary: The seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) concluded in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday with Member States adopting 11 resolutions, three decisions and a ministerial declaration aiming to advance solutions for a more resilient planet.

items.title: A sustainable future requires new thinking: UN environment report
items.summary: Adopting a fresh approach to protecting planetary health would deliver stronger economies, fewer deaths and less poverty, the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) insisted on Tuesday, as it released its most comprehensive assessment of environmental pressures facing the world.

items.title: Arab region pushed to limits by climate extremes as 2024 smashes heat records
items.summary: The Arab region is heating at nearly twice the global average, UN weather experts warned on Thursday, after 2024 saw unprecedented heat, destructive storms and worsening water scarcity impact some of the worldâ€™s most vulnerable communities.

items.title: Asia: Lives upended by cyclones, â€˜extremeâ€™ rainfall on the rise, warn UN agencies
items.summary: Across southeast Asia, record-breaking rains and flooding caused by back-to-back tropical storms have claimed hundreds of lives and brought devastation and displacement upon entire communities, UN agencies said on Tuesday.

medical.title: One stem cell generates 14 million tumor-killing NK cells in major cancer breakthrough
medical.summary: Scientists in China have unveiled a breakthrough way to mass-produce powerful cancer-fighting immune cells in the lab. By engineering early-stage stem cells from cord bloodâ€”rather than trying to modify mature natural killer (NK) cellsâ€”they created a streamlined process that generates enormous numbers of highly potent NK cells, including CAR-equipped versions designed to hunt specific cancers.

medical.title: Toxic metals found in bananas after Brazil mining disaster
medical.summary: Researchers investigating crops grown in soil contaminated by the 2015 mining disaster in Brazil discovered that toxic metals are moving from the earth into edible plants. Bananas, cassava, and cocoa were found to absorb elements like lead and cadmium, with bananas showing a potential health risk for children under six. Although adults face lower immediate danger, scientists warn that long-term exposure could carry cumulative health consequences.

medical.title: Scientists discover brain switches that clear Alzheimerâ€™s plaques
medical.summary: Researchers have identified two brain receptors that help the brain clear away amyloid beta, a hallmark of Alzheimerâ€™s disease. By stimulating these receptors in mice, scientists increased levels of a natural amyloid-breaking enzyme, reduced buildup in the brain, and improved memory-related behavior. Because these receptors are common drug targets, the findings could open the door to affordable pill-based treatments with fewer side effects.

medical.title: Nearly 200,000 people reveal the real key to heart health
medical.summary: A decades-long study of nearly 200,000 adults challenges the low-carb versus low-fat debate. Both eating patterns were tied to lower heart disease risk when they emphasized whole grains, plant-based foods, and healthy fats. Versions filled with refined carbs and animal fats increased risk instead. Quality, not just quantity, appears to make the difference.

medical.title: Giving people cash didnâ€™t cause more injuries or deaths
medical.summary: As cash transfer programs expand across the United States, critics often warn that giving people money could spark reckless behavior, leading to injuries or even deaths. But a sweeping 11-year analysis of Alaskaâ€™s long-running Permanent Fund Dividend program tells a different story. Researchers examined statewide hospital records and death data and found no increase in traumatic injuries or unnatural deaths after annual payments were distributed.

medical.title: Large study finds no link between mRNA COVID vaccine in pregnancy and autism
medical.summary: Researchers tracked more than 400 toddlers to see whether mRNA COVID-19 vaccination during or just before pregnancy was linked to autism or developmental delays. After detailed assessments of speech, motor skills, behavior, and social development, they found no meaningful differences between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups. Experts say the results provide strong reassurance about vaccine safety in pregnancy.

medical.title: Scientists found a way to plant ideas in dreams to boost creativity
medical.summary: Sleeping on a problem might be more powerful than we ever imagined. Neuroscientists at Northwestern University have shown that dreams can actually be nudged in specific directions â€” and those dream tweaks may boost creativity. By playing subtle sound cues during REM sleep, researchers prompted people to dream about unsolved brain teasers they had struggled with earlier. An astonishing 75% of participants dreamed about the cued puzzles, and those puzzles were solved far more often the next day.

medical.title: This vegan diet cut insulin use by nearly 30% in type 1 diabetes
medical.summary: A low-fat vegan dietâ€”without cutting calories or carbsâ€”may help people with type 1 diabetes significantly reduce how much insulin they need, and how much they spend on it. In a new analysis published in BMC Nutrition, participants following the plant-based plan lowered their daily insulin use by 28%, while those on a portion-controlled diet saw no meaningful change.

medical.title: This popular diet was linked to a much lower stroke risk
medical.summary: A long-term study found that women who closely followed a Mediterranean diet had a much lower risk of stroke. The strongest benefits were seen in women who ate more plant-based foods, fish, and olive oil while cutting back on red meat and saturated fats. Their risk dropped across all major stroke types, including bleeding strokes, which are less commonly studied. The findings suggest diet may be a powerful but overlooked factor in stroke prevention.

medical.title: Scientists found a gut compound that helps protect the liver
medical.summary: What a mother eats during pregnancy may quietly shape her childâ€™s liver health years down the roadâ€”but new research suggests there may be a way to tip the odds back in a healthier direction. Scientists found that a natural compound made by healthy gut bacteria dramatically reduced fatty liver disease in the offspring of mice whose mothers ate a high-fat, high-sugar diet. The compound, called indole, appeared to protect the liver, improve blood sugar, limit weight gain, and even reshape the gut microbiome in lasting ways.

The find reveals that these early hunters didnâ€™t just invent the bow and arrow earlier than once believed â€” they also knew how to enhance their weapons with toxic plant compounds to make hunts more effective.

science.summary: Long before agriculture, humans were transforming Europeâ€™s wild landscapes. Advanced simulations show that hunting and fire use by Neanderthals and Mesolithic hunter-gatherers reshaped forests and grasslands in measurable ways. By reducing populations of giant herbivores, people indirectly altered how dense vegetation became. The findings challenge the idea that prehistoric Europe was an untouched natural world.

environment.summary: The world spends billions to protect nature, but trillions are being invested in business activities that harm the environment.

environment.summary: The past 11 years have been the warmest in the modern era, while oceans continue to heat up, too, says the UN weather agency.

environment.summary: The seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) concluded in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday with Member States adopting 11 resolutions, three decisions and a ministerial declaration aiming to advance solutions for a more resilient planet.
